props.name: Rule_Description
props.value: Make sure that the dconf databases are up-to-date with regards to respective keyfiles

props.name: Parameter_Description_0
props.value: Choose allowed duration (in seconds) of inactive graphical sessions

props.name: Parameter_Description_1
props.value: Enter an appropriate login banner for your organization. Please note that new lines must be expressed by the '\n' character and special characters like parentheses and quotation marks must be escaped with '\\'.

props.name: Parameter_Description_2
props.value: Enter an appropriate login banner for your organization. Please note that new lines must be expressed by the '\n' character and special characters like parentheses and quotation marks must be escaped with '\\'.

props.name: Parameter_Description_3
props.value: Enter an appropriate login banner for your organization. Please note that new lines must be expressed by the '\n' character and special characters like parentheses and quotation marks must be escaped with '\\'.

props.name: Parameter_Description_4
props.value: Specify duration of allowed idle time.

props.name: Parameter_Description_5
props.value: Maximum age of password in days

props.name: Parameter_Description_6
props.value: Minimum age of password in days

props.name: Parameter_Description_7
props.value: The number of days' warning given before a password expires.

props.name: Parameter_Description_8
props.value:
The setting for max_log_file_action in /etc/audit/auditd.conf. The following options are available:
ignore - audit daemon does nothing.
syslog - audit daemon will issue a warning to syslog.
suspend - audit daemon will stop writing records to the disk.
rotate - audit daemon will rotate logs in the same convention used by logrotate.
keep_logs - similar to rotate but prevents audit logs to be overwritten. May trigger space_left_action if volume is full.

props.name: Parameter_Description_9
props.value: Specify the authselect profile to select

props.name: Parameter_Description_10
props.value: The list of vendor-approved time servers

props.name: Parameter_Description_11
props.value: Specify the system default encryption algorithm for encrypting passwords. Defines the value set as ENCRYPT_METHOD in /etc/login.defs.

props.name: Parameter_Description_12
props.value: Specify the system default encryption algorithm for encrypting passwords. Defines the hashing algorithm to be used in pam_unix.so.

props.name: Parameter_Description_13
props.value: Minimum number of categories of characters that must exist in a password

props.name: Parameter_Description_14
props.value: Minimum number of characters in password

props.name: Parameter_Description_15
props.value: Choose allowed duration (in seconds) after a screensaver becomes active before displaying an authentication prompt

props.name: Parameter_Description_16
props.value:
Type of policy in use. Possible values are:
targeted - Only targeted network daemons are protected.
strict - Full SELinux protection.
mls - Multiple levels of security

props.name: Parameter_Description_17
props.value:
enforcing - SELinux security policy is enforced.
permissive - SELinux prints warnings instead of enforcing.
disabled - SELinux is fully disabled.

props.name: Parameter_Description_18
props.value: Specify the maximum number of idle message counts before session is terminated.

props.name: Parameter_Description_19
props.value: Specify the crypto policy for the system.

implemented-requirements.description: This is a helper rule to reload Dconf database correctly.
The policy doesn't have any section where this would fit better.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
It is not clear the intention of this requirement since there is no definition of these
subcategories. The project has many audit related rules. Clarifying these subcategories
we can select the proper rules.

implemented-requirements.description:
We probably have audit related rule to monitor mount related syscalls, but it is not clear
about the swap. Is the intention to monitor when swap is changed?

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
It is a little tricky to interpret this requirement. Assuming the "Common users" are actually
interactive users, this requirement would automatically enforce all admin actions to be
performed only by the root user. I am not sure if this is the intetion here.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
New templated rule is necessary to install the package. But to ensure the chosen antivirus
is actually updated would demand a more complex rule. Maybe this requirement can have at
leastthe partial status after the templated rule.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: Related to nosuid, noexec and nodev options but in /boot. More context is needed.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: There are rules for ssh_keys, for example. We need to confirm the scope of this requirement

implemented-requirements.description:
These are mentioned to be reviewed but not enforced:
# net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_all = 1
# net.ipv4.tcp_timestamps = 0
# net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog = 1280
# sysctl_net_ipv6_conf_all_disable_ipv6
# sysctl_net_ipv6_conf_default_disable_ipv6

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
Is it related to downloads from the Internet to the system or from the system to an external
storage, for example?

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: Maybe simply removing the packages is enough.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
Is it related to TTY access, physical access, local users authentication, etc?
It is not not clear the scope.

implemented-requirements.description: It overlaps the rule in A.5.SEC-RHEL6 requirement

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: It seems to duplicate the A.11.SEC-RHEL4 requirement

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: More context should be provided to clarify this requirement

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: This is already covered by other requirements. Maybe more rules could be included here.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: It seems to duplicate the A.11.SEC-RHEL12 requirement.

implemented-requirements.description: This is a helper rule to reload Dconf database correctly.
The policy doesn't have any section where this would fit better.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
It is not clear the intention of this requirement since there is no definition of these
subcategories. The project has many audit related rules. Clarifying these subcategories
we can select the proper rules.

implemented-requirements.description:
We probably have audit related rule to monitor mount related syscalls, but it is not clear
about the swap. Is the intention to monitor when swap is changed?

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
It is a little tricky to interpret this requirement. Assuming the "Common users" are actually
interactive users, this requirement would automatically enforce all admin actions to be
performed only by the root user. I am not sure if this is the intetion here.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
New templated rule is necessary to install the package. But to ensure the chosen antivirus
is actually updated would demand a more complex rule. Maybe this requirement can have at
leastthe partial status after the templated rule.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: Related to nosuid, noexec and nodev options but in /boot. More context is needed.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: There are rules for ssh_keys, for example. We need to confirm the scope of this requirement

implemented-requirements.description:
These are mentioned to be reviewed but not enforced:
# net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_all = 1
# net.ipv4.tcp_timestamps = 0
# net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog = 1280
# sysctl_net_ipv6_conf_all_disable_ipv6
# sysctl_net_ipv6_conf_default_disable_ipv6

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
Is it related to downloads from the Internet to the system or from the system to an external
storage, for example?

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: Maybe simply removing the packages is enough.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks:
Is it related to TTY access, physical access, local users authentication, etc?
It is not not clear the scope.

implemented-requirements.description: It overlaps the rule in A.5.SEC-RHEL6 requirement

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: It seems to duplicate the A.11.SEC-RHEL4 requirement

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: More context should be provided to clarify this requirement

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: This is already covered by other requirements. Maybe more rules could be included here.

props.name: implementation-status
props.remarks: It seems to duplicate the A.11.SEC-RHEL12 requirement.
